section.name: s5
section.leadIn: The scales of equipment indicated in the foregoing Table shall be as follows:

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: Spare fuses for all electrical circuits the fuses of which can be replaced in flight, consisting of 10 per cent of the number of each rating or three of each rating, whichever is the greater.

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: Maps, charts, codes and other documents and navigational equipment necessary, in addition to any other equipment required under this Order, for the intended flight of the aircraft including any diversion which may reasonably be expected.

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: An accessible first-aid kit.

subparagraph.name: aa
subparagraph.content: In the case of an aeroplane, accessible and adequate medical supplies as appropriate to the number of passengers the aeroplane is authorized to carry.

subparagraph.name: bb
subparagraph.content: In the case of a helicopter or gyroplane, one or more first-aid kits as appropriate to the number of passengers the helicopter or gyroplane is authorized to carry. (L.N. 77 of 2008)

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.leadIn: In the case of a flying machine used for the public transport of passengers in which, while the flying machine is at rest on the ground, the sill of any external door intended for the disembarkation of passengers, whether normally or in an emergency:

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: is more than 1.82 metres from the ground when the undercarriage of the machine is in the normal position for taxying; or

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: would be more than 1.82 metres from the ground if the undercarriage or any part thereof should collapse, break or fail to function;

subparagraph.continued: apparatus readily available for use at each door consisting of a device or devices which will enable passengers to reach the ground safely in an emergency while the flying machine is on the ground, and can be readily fixed in position for use.

schedule.text: An altitude alerting system capable of alerting the pilot upon approaching a preselected altitude in either ascent or descent, by a sequence of visual and aural signals in sufficient time to establish level flight at that preselected altitude, and when deviating above or below that preselected altitude, by a visual and an aural signal:
schedule.proviso: Provided that if the system becomes unserviceable, the aircraft may fly or continue to fly, until it first lands at a place at which it is reasonably practicable for the system to be repaired or replaced.

content.leadIn: If the maximum total weight authorized of the aircraft is 2 730 kg or less, for every pilot’s seat and for any seat situated alongside a pilot’s seat, a safety belt with one diagonal shoulder strap or a safety harness:
content.proviso: Provided that the Chief Executive may permit a safety belt without a diagonal shoulder strap to be fitted if he is satisfied that it is not reasonably practicable to fit a safety belt with one diagonal shoulder strap or a safety harness. (36 of 1999 s. 3)

content.leadIn: If the maximum total weight authorized of the aircraft exceeds 2 730 kg, a safety harness for every pilot’s seat and for any seat situated alongside a pilot’s seat:
content.proviso: Provided that the Chief Executive may permit a safety belt with one diagonal shoulder strap to be fitted if he is satisfied that it is not reasonably practicable to fit a safety harness. (36 of 1999 s. 3)

subparagraph.name: c
subparagraph.content: For every seat in use (not being a seat referred to in subparagraphs (a), (b), (e) and (f)) a safety belt with or without one diagonal shoulder strap or a safety harness.

subparagraph.name: d
subparagraph.content: In addition and to be attached to or secured by the equipment required in subparagraph (c) above, a child restraint device for every child under the age of 2 years on board.

subparagraph.name: e
subparagraph.content: On all flights for the public transport of passengers by aircraft, for each seat for use by members of the cabin crew who are required to be carried under this Order, a safety harness.

content.leadIn: On all flights in aeroplanes the maximum total weight authorized of which does not exceed 5 700 kg which in accordance with the certificate of airworthiness in force thereof is not capable of seating more than 9 passengers (otherwise than in seats referred to in subparagraphs (a) and (b)), a safety belt with one diagonal shoulder strap or a safety harness for each seat intended for use by a passenger: (E.R. 5 of 2022)
content.proviso: Provided that the provisions of this subparagraph shall not apply to aeroplanes in respect of which a certificate of airworthiness was first issued (whether in Hong Kong or elsewhere) before 1 February 1989.

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: If the pilot in command cannot, from his own seat, see all the passengers’ seats in the aircraft, a means of indicating to the passengers that seat belts should be fastened.

content.leadIn: A safety harness for every seat in use:
content.proviso: Provided that in the case of an aircraft carrying out aerobatic manoeuvres consisting only of erect spinning, the Chief Executive may permit a safety belt with one diagonal shoulder strap to be fitted if he is satisfied that such restraint is sufficient for the carrying out of erect spinning in that aircraft and that it is not reasonably practicable to fit a safety harness in that aircraft. (36 of 1999 s. 3)

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: Equipment for displaying the lights required by the Rules of the Air;

paragraph.name: ii
iii
paragraph.content: Unless the aircraft is equipped with radio, devices for making the visual signal specified in the Rules of the Air as indicating a request for permission to land.

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: In the case of a helicopter or gyroplane, a slip indicator;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.leadIn: In the case of any other flying machine either:

subparagraph.name: aa
subparagraph.content: a turn indicator and a slip indicator; or

subparagraph.name: bb
subparagraph.content: a gyroscopic bank and pitch indicator and a gyroscopic direction indicator;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: A sensitive pressure altimeter, with counter drum-pointer or equivalent presentation, adjustable for any sea level barometric pressure which the weather report or forecasts available to the pilot in command of the aircraft indicate is likely to be encountered during the intended flight. (L.N. 77 of 2008)

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: In the case of a helicopter or gyroplane, a slip indicator;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: In the case of any other flying machine, a turn indicator and a slip indicator;

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: In the case of an aeroplane, an attitude indicator;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: In the case of a helicopter or gyroplane, an attitude indicator for each required pilot and one additional attitude indicator; (L.N. 77 of 2008)

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: A heading indicator; (L.N. 77 of 2008)

content.leadIn: A sensitive pressure altimeter, with counter drum-pointer or equivalent presentation, adjustable for any sea level barometric pressure which the weather report or forecasts available to the pilot in command of the aircraft indicate is likely to be encountered during the intended flight:

paragraph.proviso: Provided that any aircraft may, at the option of the operator, be equipped with an additional attitude indicator in lieu of the turn indicator referred to in paragraph (i) of this Scale. (L.N. 77 of 2008)

schedule.text: Scale EEA radio altimeter with an audio voice warning operating below a preset height and a visual warning capable of operating at a height selectable by the pilot.

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: A timepiece indicating the time in hours, minutes and seconds;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: A means of indicating whether the power supply to the gyroscopic instrument is adequate;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: A rate of climb and descent indicator;

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: A means of indicating in the flight crew compartment the outside air temperature; (L.N. 77 of 2008)

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: An airspeed indicating system with a means of preventing malfunction due to either condensation or icing; in the case of an aeroplane with speed limitations expressed in terms of Mach number, a Mach number indicator; (L.N. 77 of 2008)

subparagraph.name: vi
subparagraph.content: A magnetic compass. (L.N. 77 of 2008)

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.content: An electrical lighting system to provide illumination in every passenger compartment;

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: One electric torch for each member of the crew of the aircraft; or

subparagraph.name: aa
subparagraph.content: one electric torch for each member of the flight crew of the aircraft; and

subparagraph.name: bb
aaa
subparagraph.content: be readily accessible for use by the crew of the aircraft at all times; and

subparagraph.name: bbb
subparagraph.content: number in total not less than the minimum number of members of the cabin crew required to be carried with a full passenger complement; (L.N. 77 of 2008)

subparagraph.name: iv
a
subparagraph.content: In the case of a helicopter or gyroplane in respect of which there is in force a certificate of airworthiness designating the helicopter or gyroplane as being of performance group A, 2 landing lights of which at least one is adjustable in flight so as to illuminate the ground in front of and below the helicopter or gyroplane and the ground on either side of the helicopter or gyroplane;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: In the case of a helicopter or gyroplane in respect of which there is in force a certificate of airworthiness designating the helicopter or gyroplane as being of performance group B, 2 landing lights. (L.N. 77 of 2008)

schedule.text: Scale HFor each person on board, a lifejacket equipped with a whistle and waterproof torch:Provided that lifejackets constructed and carried solely for use by children under three years of age need not be equipped with a whistle.
Scale IA survival suit for each member of the crew.

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.content: Parachute distress rocket signals capable of making, from the surface of the water, the pyrotechnical signal of distress specified in the Rules of the Air and complying with Part I of Schedule 8 to the Merchant Shipping (Safety) (Life-Saving Appliances) (Ships Built On or After 1 July 1986) Regulations 1991*, made under the Merchant Shipping (Safety) Ordinance (Cap. 369);

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: A sea anchor and other equipment necessary to facilitate mooring, anchoring or manoeuvering the flying machine on water, appropriate to its size, weight and handling characteristics; (L.N. 77 of 2008)

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: Equipment for making the sound signals for preventing collisions at sea. (L.N. 77 of 2008)

tr.td: It was once Cap. 369 sub. leg. AC and was subsequently repealed by L.N. 157 of 2001.

subparagraph.name: i
a
b
subparagraph.content: In the case of a helicopter or gyroplane carrying 20 or more persons, a minimum of 2 liferafts sufficient together to accommodate all persons on board.

subparagraph.continued: Each liferaft shall contain the following equipment:

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: means for maintaining buoyancy;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: a sea anchor;

subparagraph.name: c
subparagraph.content: life-lines, and means of attaching one liferaft to another;

subparagraph.name: d
subparagraph.content: paddles or other means of propulsion;

subparagraph.name: e
subparagraph.content: means of protecting the occupants from the elements;

subparagraph.name: f
subparagraph.content: a waterproof torch;

subparagraph.name: g
subparagraph.content: marine type pyrotechnical distress signals;

subparagraph.name: h
subparagraph.content: means of making sea water drinkable, unless the full quantity of fresh water is carried as specified in item (i); (L.N. 77 of 2008)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: for each 4 or proportion of 4 persons the liferaft is designed to carry:
1/2 litre of fresh water in durable containers:
subparagraph.proviso: Provided that in any case in which it is not reasonably practicable to carry the quantity of water above specified as large a quantity of fresh water as is reasonably practicable in the circumstances may be substituted. In no case however shall the quantity of water carried be less than is sufficient, when added to the amount of fresh water capable of being produced by means of the equipment specified in item (h) to provide 1/2 litre of water for each 4 or proportion of 4 persons the liferaft is designed to carry; (L.N. 77 of 2008; E.R. 5 of 2022)

subparagraph.name: j
subparagraph.content: first aid equipment;

paragraph.continued: Items (f) to (j) inclusive shall be contained in a pack.

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content:
The number of survival beacon radio apparatus carried when the aircraft is carrying the number of liferafts specified in column 1 of the following Table shall be not less than the number specified in, or calculated in accordance with column 2.
Table
Column 1
Column 2
Not more than 8 liferafts.
2 survival beacon radio apparatus.
For every additional 4 or proportion of 4 liferafts.
1 additional survival beacon radio apparatus.

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: In the case of a helicopter or gyroplane, an emergency beacon which is automatically deployed and activated in the event of a crash.

schedule.text: Scale KKA permanent or rapidly deployable means of floatation so as to ensure a safe ditching of the helicopter or gyroplane.

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: In every flying machine which is provided with means for maintaining a pressure greater than 700 hectopascals throughout the flight in the flight crew compartment and in the compartments in which the passengers are carried: (L.N. 77 of 2008)

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.leadIn: a supply of oxygen sufficient, in the event of failure to maintain such pressure, occurring in the circumstances specified in columns 1 and 2 of the Table set out in Part II of this Scale, for continuous use, during the periods specified in column 3 of the said Table, by the persons for whom oxygen is to be provided in accordance with column 4 of that Table; and

subparagraph.name: b

subparagraph.continued: together with suitable and sufficient apparatus to enable such persons to use the oxygen.

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.leadIn: In any other flying machine:

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: a supply of oxygen sufficient for continuous use by all the crew other than the flight crew, and if passengers are carried, by 10% of the number of passengers, for any period exceeding 30 minutes during which the flying machine flies above flight level 100 but not above flight level 130 and the flight crew shall be supplied with oxygen sufficient for continuous use for any period during which the flying machine flies above flight level 100; and

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: a supply of oxygen sufficient for continuous use by all persons on board for the whole time during which the flying machine flies above flight level 130,

subparagraph.continued: together with suitable and sufficient apparatus to enable such persons to use the oxygen.

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: The quantity of oxygen required for the purpose of complying with paragraphs (i) and (ii) of this Part of this Scale shall be computed in accordance with the information and instructions relating thereto specified in the operations manual relating to the aircraft pursuant to paragraph (vi) of Part A of Schedule 11 to this Order. (E.R. 5 of 2022)

tr.td: The whole period during which, after a failure to maintain a pressure greater than 700 hectopascals in the control compartment and in the compartments in which passengers are carried has occurred, the flying machine flies above flight level 100. (L.N. 77 of 2008)
The whole period during which, after a failure to maintain such pressure has occurred, the flying machine flies above flight level 150.
The whole period during which, after a failure to maintain such pressure has occurred, the flying machine flies above flight level 100, but not above flight level 150.

The flying machine is capable, at the time when a failure to maintain such pressure occurs, of descending in accordance with the emergency descent procedure specified in the relevant flight manual and without flying below the minimum altitudes for safe flight specified in the operations manual relating to the aircraft, to flight level 150 within 6 minutes, and of continuing at or below that flight level to its place of intended destination or any other place at which a safe landing can be made.

The flying machine is capable, at the time when a failure to maintain such pressure occurs, of descending in accordance with the emergency descent procedure specified in the relevant flight manual and without flying below the minimum altitudes for safe flight specified in the operations manual relating to the aircraft, to flight level 150 within 4 minutes, and of continuing at or below that flight level to its place of intended destination or any other place at which a safe landing can be made.

text.content: A supply of oxygen and the associated equipment to meet the requirements set out in Parts I and II of this Scale. The duration for the purposes of this Scale shall be: (E.R. 5 of 2022)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: that calculated in accordance with the operations manual prior to the commencement of the flight, being the period or periods which it is reasonably anticipated that the aircraft will be flown in the circumstances of the intended flight at a height where the said requirements apply and in calculating the said duration account shall be taken of:

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: in the case of pressurised aircraft, the possibility of depressurisation when flying above flight level 100;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: the possibility of failure of one or more of the aircraft engines;

subparagraph.name: c
subparagraph.content: restrictions due to required minimum safe altitude;

subparagraph.name: d
subparagraph.content: fuel requirement; and

subparagraph.name: e
subparagraph.content: the performance of the aircraft; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the period or periods during which the aircraft is actually flown in the circumstances specified in the said Parts;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: When flying at or below flight level 100:
Nil

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: When flying above flight level 100 but not exceeding flight level 120:

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Members of the flight crew

tr.td: Any period during which the aircraft flies above flight level 100.

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Members of the cabin crew and 10 per cent of passengers

tr.td: For any continuous period exceeding 30 minutes during which the aircraft flies above flight level 100 but not exceeding flight level 120, the duration shall be the period by which 30 minutes is exceeded.

paragraph.name: iii
paragraph.content: When flying above flight level 120:

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Members of the flight crew

tr.td: Any period during which the aircraft flies above flight level 120.

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Members of the cabin crew and all passengers

tr.td: Any period during which the aircraft flies above flight level 120.

Nil

paragraph.name: bb

tr.td: The flying machine is capable, at the time when a failure to maintain cabin pressurisation occurs, of descending in accordance with the emergency descent procedure specified in the relevant flight manual and without flying below the minimum altitudes for safe flight specified in the operations manual relating to the aircraft, to flight level 130 within 4 minutes and of continuing at or below that flight level to its place of intended destination or any other place at which a safe landing can be made. (L.N. 77 of 2008)

part.text: Scale MEquipment to prevent the impairment through ice formation of the functioning of the controls, means of propulsion, lifting surfaces, windows or equipment of the aircraft so as to endanger the safety of the aircraft.
Scale NAn intercommunication system for use by all members of the flight crew and including microphones, not of a hand-held type, for use by the pilot and flight engineer (if any).
part.leadIn: A radar set capable of giving warning to the pilot in command of the aircraft and to the co-pilot of the presence of cumulo-nimbus clouds and other potentially hazardous weather conditions:
part.proviso: Provided that a flight may commence if the set is unserviceable or continue if the set becomes unserviceable thereafter:

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: so as to give the warning only to one pilot, so long as the aircraft is flying only to the place at which it first becomes reasonably practicable for the set to be repaired; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: when the weather report or forecasts available to the pilot in command of the aircraft indicate that cumulo-nimbus clouds or other potentially hazardous weather conditions, which can be detected by the set when in working order, are unlikely to be encountered on the intended route or any planned diversion therefrom or the pilot in command has satisfied himself that any such weather conditions will be encountered in daylight and can be seen and avoided, and the aircraft is in either case operated throughout the flight in accordance with any relevant instructions given in the operations manual. (L.N. 77 of 2008)

part.leadIn: A flight data recorder which is capable of recording and retaining the data recorded during at least the last 25 hours of its operation, by reference to a time-scale, the following data: (L.N. 77 of 2008)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: indicated airspeed;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: indicated altitude;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: vertical acceleration;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: magnetic heading;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: pitch attitude, if the equipment provided in the aeroplane is of such a nature as to enable this item to be recorded;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: engine power, if the equipment provided in the aeroplane is of such a nature as to enable this item to be recorded;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: flap position;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.leadIn: roll attitude, if the equipment provided in the aeroplane is of such a nature as to enable this item to be recorded:

part.proviso: Provided that any aeroplane having a maximum total weight authorized not exceeding 11 400 kg may be provided with:

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: a flight data recorder capable of recording the data described in subparagraphs (a) to (h) of this Scale; or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: a 4 channel cockpit voice recorder.

part.continued: In addition, on all flights by turbine-powered aeroplanes having a maximum total weight authorized exceeding 11 400 kg, a 4 channel cockpit voice recorder.
The flight data recorder and cockpit voice recorder referred to above shall be so constructed that the record would be likely to be preserved in the event of an accident to the aeroplane:
part.proviso: Provided that an aeroplane shall not be required to carry the said equipment, if before take-off the equipment is found to be unserviceable and the aircraft flies in accordance with arrangements approved by the Chief Executive. (36 of 1999 s. 3)
part.text: Scale QIf the maximum total weight authorized of the aeroplane exceeds 5 700 kg and it was first registered, whether in Hong Kong or elsewhere, on or after 1 June 1965, a door between the flight crew compartment and any adjacent compartment to which passengers have access, which door shall be fitted with a lock or bolt capable of being worked from the flight crew compartment.

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: In respect of aeroplanes having a maximum total weight authorized exceeding 5 700 kg, equipment sufficient to protect the eyes, nose and mouth of all members of the flight crew required to be carried by virtue of Article 18 of this Order for a period of not less than 15 minutes and, in addition, where the minimum flight crew required as aforesaid is more than one and a member of the cabin crew is not required to be carried by virtue of Article 18 of this Order; portable equipment sufficient to protect the eyes, nose and mouth of one member of the flight crew for a period of not less than 15 minutes;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.leadIn: In respect of aeroplanes having a maximum total weight authorized not exceeding 5 700 kg, the equipment specified in (i)(a) of this Scale:
subparagraph.proviso: Provided that in the case of such aeroplanes restricted by virtue of the operator’s operations manual to flight at or below flight level 250 and capable of descending as specified at A hereunder such equipment shall be sufficient to protect the eyes only.

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: In respect of aeroplanes having a maximum total weight authorized exceeding 5 700 kg, portable equipment to protect the eyes, nose and mouth of all members of the cabin crew required to be carried by virtue of Article 18 of this Order for a period of not less than 15 minutes;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.leadIn: In respect of aeroplanes having a maximum total weight authorized not exceeding 5 700 kg, the equipment specified in (ii)(a) of this Scale:
subparagraph.proviso: Provided that this requirement shall not apply to such aeroplanes restricted by virtue of the operator’s operations manual to flight at or below flight level 250 and capable of descending as specified at A hereunder.

tr.td: The aeroplane is capable of descending in accordance with the emergency descent procedure specified in the relevant flight manual and without flying below the minimum altitudes for safe flight specified in the operations manual relating to the aeroplane, to flight level 100 within 4 minutes and of continuing at or below that flight level to its place of intended destination or any other place at which a safe landing can be made.

part.text: Scale SA flight data recorder required by this Scale shall be capable of retaining the data recorded during at least the last 25 hours of its operation. A cockpit voice recorder required by this Scale shall be capable of retaining the data recorded during at least the last 30 minutes of its operation. For a cockpit voice recorder installed in an aeroplane of a maximum total weight authorized exceeding 5 700 kg for which an individual certificate of airworthiness was first issued after 1 January 2003, it shall be capable of retaining the data recorded during at least the last 2 hours of its operation.

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: either a 4 channel cockpit voice recorder or a flight data recorder capable of recording by reference to a time scale the data required to determine the following matters accurately in respect of the aeroplane: the flight path, attitude and the basic lift, thrust and drag forces acting upon it;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a 4 channel cockpit voice recorder and a flight data recorder capable of recording by reference to a time scale the data required to determine the following matters accurately in respect of the aeroplane: the information specified in paragraph (i) of this Scale together with use of VHF transmitters;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.leadIn: a 4 channel cockpit voice recorder and a flight data recorder capable of recording by reference to a time scale the data required to determine the following matters accurately in respect of the aeroplane: the flight path, attitude, the basic lift, thrust and drag forces acting upon it, the selection of high lift devices (if any) and airbrakes (if any), the position of primary flying control and pitch trim surfaces, outside air temperature, instrument landing system deviations, use of automatic flight control systems, use of VHF transmitters, radio altitude (if any), cockpit warnings relating to engine fire and engine shut-down, cabin pressurisation, presence of smoke and hydraulic/pneumatic power supply;

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: either a cockpit voice recorder and a flight data recorder or a combined cockpit voice recorder/flight data recorder capable in either case of recording by reference to a time scale the data required to determine the following matters accurately in respect of the aeroplane: the flight path, speed, attitude, engine power, outside air temperature, configuration of lift and drag devices, use of VHF transmitters and use of automatic flight control systems;

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: a cockpit voice recorder and a flight data recorder capable of recording by reference to a time scale the data required to determine the following matters accurately in respect of the aeroplane: the flight path, speed, attitude, engine power, outside air temperature, configuration of lift and drag devices, use of VHF transmitters and use of automatic flight control systems;

subparagraph.name: vi
subparagraph.content: a cockpit voice recorder and a flight data recorder capable of recording by reference to a time scale the data required to determine the following matters accurately in respect of the aeroplane: the flight path, speed, attitude, engine power, outside air temperature, instrument landing system deviations, marker beacon passage, radio altitude, configuration of the landing gear and lift and drag devices, position of primary flying controls and pitch trim position, use of automatic flight control systems, use of VHF transmitters, ground speed/drift angle or latitude/longitude if the navigational equipment provided in the aeroplane is of such a nature as to enable this information to be recorded with reasonable practicability, cockpit warnings relating to ground proximity and the master warning system;

subparagraph.name: viii
subparagraph.content: a cockpit voice recorder and a Type IA flight data recorder as described in paragraph 6.3.1.8 in Part I and paragraph 6.10.1.7 in Part II of Annex 6 to the Chicago Convention as amended by all amendments up to and including Amendment 31 to that Part I and all amendments up to and including Amendment 26 to that Part II. (L.N. 77 of 2008)

part.continued: The cockpit voice recorder or flight data recorder or combined cockpit voice recorder/flight data recorder, as the case may be, shall be so constructed that the record would be likely to be preserved in the event of an accident:
part.proviso: Provided that an aircraft shall not be required to carry the said equipment, if before take-off the equipment is found to be unserviceable and the aircraft flies in accordance with arrangements approved by the Chief Executive. (36 of 1999 s. 3)
part.leadIn: Scale SSFor a cockpit voice recorder required by this Scale but installed in helicopters for which an individual certificate of airworthiness was first issued after 1 January 2003, it shall be capable of retaining the data recorded during at least the last 2 hours of its operation. (L.N. 77 of 2008)

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.leadIn: A 4 channel cockpit voice recorder capable of recording and retaining the data recorded during at least the last 30 minutes of its operation and a flight data recorder capable of recording and retaining the data recorded during at least the last 10 hours of its operation being the data required to determine by reference to a time scale the following matters accurately in respect of the helicopter or gyroplane:

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: flight path;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: speed;

subparagraph.name: c
subparagraph.content: attitude;

subparagraph.name: d
subparagraph.content: engine power;

subparagraph.name: e
subparagraph.content: main rotor speed;

subparagraph.name: f
subparagraph.content: outside air temperature;

subparagraph.name: g
subparagraph.content: position of pilot’s primary flight controls;

subparagraph.name: h
subparagraph.content: use of VHF transmitters;

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: use of automatic flight controls (if any);

subparagraph.name: j
subparagraph.content: use of stability augmentation system (if any);

subparagraph.name: k
subparagraph.content: cockpit warnings relating to the master warning system; and

subparagraph.name: l
subparagraph.content: selection of hydraulic system and cockpit warnings of failure of essential hydraulic systems.

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.leadIn: A 4 channel cockpit voice recorder capable of recording and retaining the data recorded during at least the last 30 minutes of its operation and a flight data recorder capable of recording and retaining the data recorded during at least the last 10 hours of its operation being the data required to determine by reference to a time scale the information specified in paragraph (i) of this Scale together with the following matters accurately in respect of the helicopter or gyroplane:

subparagraph.name: m
subparagraph.content: landing gear configuration;

subparagraph.name: n
o
subparagraph.content: radio altitude;

subparagraph.name: p
subparagraph.content: instrument landing system deviations;

subparagraph.name: q
subparagraph.content: marker beacon passage;

subparagraph.name: r
subparagraph.content: ground speed/drift angle or latitude/longitude if the navigational equipment provided in the helicopter or gyroplane is of such a nature as to enable this information to be recorded with reasonable practicability; and

subparagraph.name: s
subparagraph.content: main gear box oil temperature and pressure.

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.leadIn: A combined cockpit voice recorder/flight data recorder which meets the following requirements:

subparagraph.name: aa
subparagraph.content: in the case of a helicopter or gyroplane which is otherwise required to carry a flight data recorder specified at paragraph (i) of this Scale the flight data recorder shall be capable of recording the data specified therein and retaining it for the duration therein specified;

subparagraph.name: bb
subparagraph.content: in the case of a helicopter or gyroplane which is otherwise required to carry a flight data recorder specified at paragraph (ii) of this Scale, the flight data recorder shall be capable of recording the data specified therein and retaining it for the duration therein specified;

subparagraph.name: cc
subparagraph.content: the cockpit voice recorder shall be capable of recording and retaining at least the last hour of cockpit voice recording information on not less than three separate channels.

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.leadIn: In any case when a combined cockpit voice recorder/flight data recorder specified at paragraph (iii)(a) of this Scale is required to be carried by or under this Order, the flight data recorder shall be capable of retaining as protected data the data recorded during at least the last 5 hours of its operation or the maximum duration of the flight, whichever is the greater. It shall also be capable of retaining additional data as unprotected data for a period which together with the period for which protected data is required to be retained amounts to a total of 10 hours:
subparagraph.proviso: Provided that the flight data recorder need not be capable of retaining the said additional data if additional data is retained which relates to the period immediately preceding the period to which the required protected data relates or for such other period or periods that the Chief Executive may permit pursuant to Article 37 of this Order and the additional data is retained in accordance with arrangements approved by the Chief Executive. (36 of 1999 s. 3; E.R. 1 of 2013)

paragraph.name: iv
paragraph.content: A cockpit voice recorder and a Type IVA flight data recorder as described in Attachment B to Part III of Annex 6 to the Chicago Convention as amended by all amendments up to and including Amendment 12 to that Part III with a recording duration of at least 10 hours. (L.N. 77 of 2008)

paragraph.continued: With the exception of flight data which it is expressly stated above may be unprotected, the cockpit voice recorder, flight data recorder or combined cockpit voice recorder and flight data recorder, as the case may be, shall be so constructed and installed that the record (herein referred to as protected data) would be likely to be preserved in the event of an accident and each cockpit voice recorder, flight data recorder or combined cockpit voice recorder/flight data recorder required to be carried on the helicopter or gyroplane shall have attached an automatically activated underwater sonar location device or an emergency locator radio transmitter as appropriate:
paragraph.proviso: Provided that a helicopter or gyroplane shall not be required to carry the said equipment if, before take-off, the equipment is found to be unserviceable and the aircraft flies in accordance with arrangements approved by the Chief Executive. (36 of 1999 s. 3)

part.text: An underwater sonar location device except in respect of those helicopters or gyroplanes which have a device attached to a cockpit voice recorder in accordance with Scale S or are required to carry equipment in accordance with Scale SS.

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.leadIn: 1 survival beacon radio apparatus;

subparagraph.name: b

subparagraph.name: c
subparagraph.content: for each 4 or proportion of 4 persons on board, 100 grammes of glucose toffee tablets;

subparagraph.name: b

subparagraph.name: d
subparagraph.content: for each 4 or proportion of 4 persons on board, 1/2 litre of fresh water in durable containers;

subparagraph.name: f
subparagraph.content: for every 75 or proportion of 75 persons on board, 1 stove suitable for use with aircraft fuel;

subparagraph.name: g

subparagraph.name: h
subparagraph.content: 2 snow shovels;

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: 2 ice saws;

subparagraph.name: j
subparagraph.content: single or multiple sleeping-bags, sufficient for the use of one-third of all persons on board;

subparagraph.name: k
subparagraph.content: 1 Arctic suit for each member of the crew of the aircraft.

text.leadIn: Cosmic radiation detection equipment calibrated in millirems per hour and capable of indicating the action and alert levels of radiation does rate:
text.proviso: Provided that an aircraft shall not be required to carry the said equipment if before take-off the equipment is found to be unserviceable and it is not reasonably practicable to repair or replace it at the aerodrome of departure and the radiation forecast available to the pilot in command of the aircraft indicates that hazardous radiation conditions are unlikely to be encountered by the aircraft on its intended route or any planned diversion therefrom.

text.leadIn: A ground proximity warning system which has a forward looking terrain avoidance function:
text.proviso: Provided that if the equipment becomes unserviceable, the aircraft may fly or continue to fly until it first lands at a place at which it is reasonably practicable for the equipment to be repaired or replaced.

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: If the aircraft may in accordance with its certificate of airworthiness carry more than 19 and less than 100 passengers, one portable battery-powered megaphone capable of conveying instructions to all persons in the passenger compartment and readily available for use by a member of the crew.

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: If the aircraft may in accordance with its certificate of airworthiness carry more than 99 and less than 200 passengers, 2 portable battery-powered megaphones together capable of conveying instructions to all persons in the passenger compartment and each readily available for use by a member of the crew.

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: If the aircraft may in accordance with its certificate of airworthiness carry more than 199 passengers, 3 portable battery-powered megaphones together capable of conveying instructions to all persons in the passenger compartment and each readily available for use by a member of the crew.

subparagraph.leadIn: If the aircraft may in accordance with its certificate of airworthiness carry more than 19 passengers:

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: a public address system; and

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: an interphone system of communication between members of the flight crew and members of the cabin crew. (L.N. 77 of 2008)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: An emergency lighting system to provide illumination in the passenger compartment sufficient to facilitate the evacuation of the aircraft notwithstanding the failure of the lighting systems specified in paragraph (ii) of Scale G.

subparagraph.content: An emergency lighting system to provide illumination outside the aircraft sufficient to facilitate the evacuation of the aircraft.

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: A serviceable autopilot that has at least altitude hold and heading select modes;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: A headset with a boom microphone or equivalent; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: Means of displaying charts that enables them to be readable in all ambient light conditions.

schedule.name: sch6

content.leadIn: Every aircraft shall be provided, when flying in the circumstances specified in the first column of the Table set forth in paragraph 2 of this Schedule, with the scales of equipment respectively indicated in that Table:

paragraph.content: All aircraft within Hong Kong:

paragraph.name: c

All aircraft registered in Hong Kong, wherever they may be:

paragraph.name: a

paragraph.name: i

over a route on which navigation is effected solely by visual reference to landmarks.

schedule.text: * Unless the appropriate air traffic control unit otherwise permits in relation to the particular flight and provided that the aircraft complies with any instructions which the air traffic control unit may give in the particular case.

section.name: s3
section.content: The scales of radio and radio navigation equipment indicated in the foregoing Table shall be as follows:

content.text: Radio equipment capable of maintaining direct two-way communication with the appropriate aeronautical radio stations.
Radio navigation equipment capable of enabling the aircraft to be navigated on the intended route including such equipment as may be prescribed.
Radio equipment capable of receiving from the appropriate aeronautical radio stations meteorological broadcasts relevant to the intended flight.

Radio navigation equipment capable of receiving signals from one or more aeronautical radio stations on the surface to enable the aircraft to be guided to a point from which a visual landing can be made at the aerodrome at which the aircraft is to land.

Secondary surveillance radar equipment which includes a pressure altitude reporting transponder capable of operating in Mode A and Mode C and is capable of being operated in accordance with such instructions as may be given to the aircraft by the air traffic control unit.(L.N. 77 of 2008)
content.leadIn: Radio and radio navigation equipment capable of enabling the aircraft to be navigated along the intended route including:

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: automatic direction finding equipment;

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: distance measuring equipment; and

paragraph.name: iii
paragraph.content: VHF omni-range equipment.

content.text: Radio navigation equipment capable of enabling the aircraft to make an approach to landing using the Instrument Landing System.
content.leadIn: Radio navigation equipment capable of enabling the aircraft to be navigated on the intended route including:

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: automatic direction finding equipment;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: distance measuring equipment;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: duplicated VHF omni-range equipment; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a 75 MHz marker beacon receiver.

content.leadIn: Except that an aircraft may fly notwithstanding that it does not carry the equipment specified in this Scale if it carries alternate radio navigation equipment or navigational equipment approved by the Chief Executive in writing in accordance with the provisions of Article 13(7) of this Order. (36 of 1999 s. 3)
Where not more than one item of equipment specified in this Scale is unserviceable when the aircraft is about to begin a flight, the aircraft may nevertheless take off on that flight if:

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: it is not reasonably practicable for the repair or replacement of that item to be carried out before the beginning of the flight;

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: the aircraft has not made more than one flight since the item was last serviceable; and

paragraph.name: iii
paragraph.content: the commander of the aircraft has satisfied himself that, taking into account the latest information available as to the route and aerodrome to be used (including any planned diversion) and the weather conditions likely to be encountered, the flight can be made safely and in accordance with any relevant requirements of the appropriate air traffic control unit.

section.name: s4
section.leadIn: In this Schedule—

subsection.def: automatic direction finding equipment means radio navigation equipment which automatically indicates the bearing of any radio station transmitting the signals received by such equipment;

VHF omni-range equipment means radio navigation equipment capable of giving visual indications of bearings of the aircraft by means of signals received from very high frequency omni-directional radio ranges;

distance measuring equipment means radio navigation equipment capable of providing a continuous indication of the aircraft’s distance from the appropriate aeronautical radio stations; (L.N. 77 of 2008)

secondary surveillance radar equipment means such type of radio navigation equipment as may be notified as being capable of (a) replying to an interrogation from secondary surveillance radar units on the surface and (b) being operated in accordance with such instructions as may be given to the aircraft by the appropriate air traffic control unit; (L.N. 77 of 2008)

def.name: AirborneCollisionAvoidanceSystem
def.leadIn: airborne collision avoidance system means an aeroplane system which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is designed to provide advice and appropriate avoidance manoeuvres to the pilot in relation to other aeroplanes which are equipped with secondary surveillance radar transponders and are in undue proximity;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is based on secondary surveillance radar transponder signals;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: operates independently of ground based equipment; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: conforms to requirements specified for the purpose; (L.N. 77 of 2008)

subsection.def: Mode A means replying to an interrogation from secondary surveillance radar units on the surface to elicit transponder replies for identity and surveillance with identity provided in the form of a 4 digit identity code; and (L.N. 77 of 2008)

Mode C means replying to an interrogation from secondary surveillance radar units on the surface to elicit transponder replies for automatic pressure-altitude transmission and surveillance. (L.N. 77 of 2008)

schedule.name: sch7
schedule.heading: Aircraft, Engine and Propeller Log Books

section.name: s1
section.heading: Aircraft Log Book
section.leadIn: The following entries shall be included in the aircraft log book:

subsection.name: a
b
subsection.content: the nationality and registration marks of the aircraft;

subsection.name: c
subsection.content: the name and address of the operator of the aircraft;

subsection.name: d
subsection.content: the date of each flight and the duration of the period between take-off and landing, or, if more than one flight was made on that day, the number of flights and the total duration of the periods between take-offs and landings on that day;

subsection.name: e
subsection.content: particulars of all maintenance work carried out on the aircraft or its equipment;

subsection.name: f
subsection.content: particulars of any defects occurring in the aircraft or in any equipment required to be carried therein by or under this Order, and of the action taken to rectify such defects including a reference to the relevant entries in the technical log required by Article 10(2) and (3) of this Order;

content.leadIn: particulars of any overhauls, repairs, replacements and modifications relating to the aircraft or any such equipment as aforesaid:
content.proviso: Provided that entries shall not be required to be made under subparagraphs (e), (f) and (g) in respect of any engine or variable pitch propeller.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Engine Log Book
section.leadIn: The following entries shall be included in the engine log book:

subsection.name: a
subsection.content: the name of the constructor, the type of the engine, the number assigned to it by the constructor and the date of the construction of the engine;

subsection.name: b
subsection.content: the nationality and registration marks of each aircraft in which the engine is fitted;

subsection.name: c
subsection.content: the name and address of the operator of each such aircraft;

subsection.name: d
subsection.leadIn: either:

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: the date of each flight and the duration of the period between take-off and landing or, if more than one flight was made on that day, the number of flights and the total duration of the periods between take-offs and landings on that day; or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: the aggregate duration of periods between take-off and landing for all flights made by that aircraft since the immediately preceding occasion that any maintenance, overhaul, repair, replacement, modification or inspection was undertaken on the engine;

subsection.name: e
subsection.content: particulars of all maintenance work done on the engine;

subsection.name: f
g
subsection.content: particulars of all overhauls, repairs, replacements and modifications relating to the engine or any of its accessories.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Variable Pitch Propeller Log Book
section.leadIn: The following entries shall be included in the variable pitch propeller log book:

subsection.name: a
b
subsection.content: the nationality and registration marks of each aircraft, and the type and number of each engine, to which the propeller is fitted;

subsection.name: c
subsection.content: the name and address of the operator of each such aircraft;

subsection.name: d
subsection.leadIn: either:

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: the date of each flight and the duration of the period between take off and landing or, if more than one flight was made on that day, the number of flights and the total duration of the periods between take-offs and landings on that day; or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: the aggregate duration of periods between take-off and landing for all flights made by that aircraft since the immediately preceding occasion that any maintenance, overhaul, repair, replacement, modification or inspection was undertaken on the propeller;

subsection.name: e
subsection.content: particulars of all maintenance work done on the propeller;

subsection.name: f
g
subsection.content: particulars of any overhauls, repairs, replacements and modifications relating to the propeller.

schedule.name: sch9
schedule.heading: Flight Crew of Aircraft, Licences and Ratings

text.b: Minimum Age, Period of Validity, Privileges

content.text:
Minimum age—17 years
No Maximum Period of Validity

Privileges: The holder of the licence shall be entitled to fly as pilot in command or co-pilot of an aeroplane of any of the types specified or otherwise falling within the aircraft rating included in the licence:

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: he shall not fly such an aeroplane for the purpose of public transport or aerial work save as hereinafter provided—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: he may fly such an aeroplane for the purpose of aerial work which consists of:

subparagraph.name: aa
subparagraph.content: the giving of instruction in flying, if his licence includes a flying instructor’s rating or an assistant flying instructor’s rating; or

subparagraph.name: bb
subparagraph.content: the conducting of flying tests for the purposes of this Order,

paragraph.continued: in either case in an aeroplane owned, or operated under arrangements entered into, by a flying club of which the person giving the instruction or conducting the test and the person receiving the instruction or undergoing the test are both members;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.leadIn: he may fly such an aeroplane for the purpose of aerial work which consists of:

subparagraph.name: aa
subparagraph.content: towing a glider in flights; or

subparagraph.name: bb
subparagraph.content: a flight for the purpose of dropping of persons by parachute,

paragraph.continued: in either case in an aeroplane owned, or operated under arrangements entered into by a club of which the holder of the licence and any person carried in the aircraft or in any glider towed by the aircraft are members;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he shall not receive any remuneration for his services as a pilot, other than remuneration for the giving of such instruction or the conducting of such flying tests as are specified in subparagraph (a)(i) of this proviso;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: he shall not, unless his licence includes an instrument rating (aeroplanes), fly as pilot in command of such an aeroplane—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: on a flight outside controlled airspace when the flight visibility is less than 3 kilometres;

subparagraph.name: ii
iii
subparagraph.content: out of sight of the surface; (L.N. 77 of 2008)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: he shall not fly as pilot in command of such an aeroplane at night unless—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: his licence includes a night rating (aeroplanes), and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: his licence includes an instrument rating (aeroplanes) or he has within the immediately preceding 13 months carried out as pilot in command not less than 5 take-offs and 5 landings at a time when the depression of the centre of the sun was not less than 12° below the horizon; and (L.N. 77 of 2008)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: he shall not, unless his licence includes an instrument rating (aeroplanes), fly as pilot in command or co-pilot of such an aeroplane flying in controlled airspace notified for the purposes of this Schedule in circumstances which require compliance with the Instrument Flight Rules. (L.N. 77 of 2008)

content.text:
Minimum Age—18 years
Maximum Period of Validity—10 years

subsection.leadIn: The holder of the licence shall be entitled to exercise the privileges of a Private Pilot’s Licence (Aeroplanes) which includes a night rating (aeroplanes) and shall be entitled to fly as pilot in command of an aeroplane—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on a special VFR flight notwithstanding that the flight visibility is less than 3 kilometres;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: when the aeroplane is taking off or landing at any place notwithstanding that the flight visibility below cloud is less than 1 800 metres. (L.N. 77 of 2008)

subsection.content: He shall be entitled to fly as pilot in command of an aeroplane of a type specified in Part 1 of the aircraft rating included in the licence when the aeroplane is engaged on a flight for any purpose whatsoever:

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he shall not, unless his licence includes an instrument rating (aeroplanes), fly such an aeroplane on any scheduled journey;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he shall not fly such an aeroplane at night unless his licence includes an instrument rating (aeroplanes) or he has within the immediately preceding 13 months carried out as pilot in command not less than five take-offs and five landings at a time when the depression of the centre of the sun was not less than 12° below the horizon;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: he shall not, unless his licence includes an instrument rating (aeroplanes), fly any such aeroplane of which the maximum total weight authorized exceeds 2 300 kg on any flight for the purpose of public transport, except a flight beginning and ending at the same aerodrome and not extending beyond 25 nautical miles from that aerodrome;

paragraph.name: d
f
paragraph.content: he shall not, unless his licence includes an instrument rating (aeroplanes), fly as pilot in command or co-pilot of such an aeroplane flying in controlled airspace notified for the purpose of this Schedule in circumstances which require compliance with the Instrument Flight Rules. (L.N. 77 of 2008)

subsection.content: He shall be entitled to fly as co-pilot of any aeroplane of a type specified in the aircraft rating included in the licence when the aeroplane is engaged on a flight for any purpose whatsoever. (L.N. 77 of 2008)

subsection.leadIn: Subject to paragraph (6), he shall be entitled to fly as pilot in command of an aeroplane of a type specified in any flying instructor’s rating or assistant flying instructor’s rating included in the licence on a flight for the purpose of aerial work which consists of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the giving of instruction in flying; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the conducting of flying tests for the purposes of this Order,

subsection.continued: in either case in an aeroplane owned, or operated under arrangements entered into, by a flying club of which the person giving the instruction or conducting the test and the person receiving the instruction or undergoing the test are both members. (L.N. 77 of 2008)

subsection.content: He shall not be entitled to exercise the privileges contained in paragraph (5) other than in an aeroplane which he is entitled to fly as pilot in command on a private flight, an aerial work flight or a public transport flight pursuant to the privileges set out in paragraph (1) or (2) of these privileges. (L.N. 77 of 2008)

He shall not at any time after he attains the age of 60 years fly as pilot in command or co-pilot of any aeroplane on any flight for the purpose of public transport unless the aeroplane is fitted with dual controls and carries a second pilot who has not attained the age of 60 years and who holds an appropriate licence under this Order entitling him to act as pilot in command or co-pilot of that aeroplane. (L.N. 77 of 2008)
He shall not at any time after he attains the age of 65 years act as pilot in command or co-pilot of any aeroplane on a flight for the purpose of public transport. (L.N. 77 of 2008)

content.text:
Minimum Age—18 years
Maximum Period of Validity—10 years

subsection.leadIn: The holder of the licence shall be entitled to fly as co-pilot of any aeroplane of a type specified in the aircraft rating included in the licence when the aeroplane is required to be operated with more than one pilot and is engaged on a flight for any purpose whatsoever:

proviso.name: proviso
proviso.leadIn: Provided that—(a)he shall not, unless his licence includes an instrument rating (aeroplanes), fly such an aeroplane on any scheduled journey;(b)he shall not fly such an aeroplane on any flight for the purpose of public transport after he attains the age of 60 years unless the aeroplane is fitted with dual controls and carries a second pilot who has not attained the age of 60 years and who holds an appropriate licence under this Order entitling him to act as pilot in command of that aeroplane;(c)he shall not at any time after he attains the age of 65 years fly such an aeroplane on any flight for the purposes of public transport.

subsection.content: He shall be entitled to exercise the privileges of a Private Pilot’s Licence (Aeroplanes) in an aeroplane of any of the groups or types specified in his licence provided that the requirements for the issue of a Private Pilot’s Licence (Aeroplanes) are met and that his licence carries an appropriate endorsement which enables him to do so.

He shall be entitled to exercise the privileges of his instrument rating (aeroplanes) in a single pilot operation provided that he has demonstrated to the Chief Executive the ability to act as pilot in command in a single pilot operation exercised solely by reference to instruments and that his licence carries an appropriate endorsement which enables him to do so.

content.text:
Minimum Age—21 years
Maximum Period of Validity—10 years
content.content: Privileges: The holder of the licence shall be entitled to exercise the privileges of a Commercial Pilot’s Licence (Aeroplanes) except the proviso (d) to paragraph (2) of those privileges shall not apply. (L.N. 77 of 2008)

content.text:
Minimum Age—17 years
No Maximum Period of Validity
content.continued: Privileges: The holder of the licence shall be entitled to fly as pilot in command or co-pilot of a helicopter or gyroplane of any of the types specified in the aircraft rating included in the licence: (E.R. 5 of 2022)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: he shall not fly such a helicopter or gyroplane for the purpose of public transport or aerial work other than aerial work which consists of—

subparagraph.name: i
ii

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he shall not receive any remuneration for his services as a pilot on a flight other than remuneration for the giving of such instruction or the conducting of such flying tests as are specified in paragraph (a) of this proviso;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: he shall not fly as pilot in command of such a gyroplane at night unless his licence includes a night rating (helicopters and gyroplanes) and he has within the immediately preceding 13 months carried out as pilot in command not less than 5 take-offs and 5 landings at a time when the depression of the centre of the sun was not less than 12° below the horizon;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: he shall not fly as pilot in command of such a helicopter at night unless—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: his licence includes a night rating (helicopters and gyroplanes); and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: his licence includes an instrument rating (helicopters) or he has within the immediately preceding 13 months carried out as pilot in command not less than 5 flights, each consisting of a take-off, a transition from hover to forward flight, a climb to at least 500 feet and a landing, at a time when the depression of the centre of the sun was not less than 12° below the horizon;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: he shall not unless his licence includes an instrument rating (helicopters) fly as pilot in command or co-pilot of such a helicopter flying in controlled airspace notified for the purposes of this Schedule in circumstances which require compliance with the Instrument Flight Rules. (L.N. 77 of 2008)

section.name: s0
section.text:
Minimum Age—18 years
Maximum Period of Validity—10 years

subsection.content: The holder of the licence shall be entitled to exercise the privileges of a Private Pilot’s Licence (Helicopters and Gyroplanes) which includes a night rating (helicopters and gyroplanes).

subsection.leadIn: He shall be entitled to fly as pilot in command of any helicopter or gyroplane specified in Part 1 of the aircraft rating included in the licence when the helicopter or gyroplane is engaged on a flight for any purpose whatsoever:

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he shall not, unless his licence includes an instrument rating (helicopters), fly such a helicopter on any scheduled journey or on any flight for the purpose of public transport in Instrument Meteorological Conditions;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: he shall not fly such a gyroplane at night unless he has within the immediately preceding 13 months carried out as a pilot in command not less than 5 take-offs and 5 landings at a time when the depression of the centre of the sun was not less than 12° below the horizon;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: he shall not fly such a helicopter at night unless his licence includes an instrument rating (helicopters) or he has within the immediately preceding 13 months carried out as pilot in command not less than 5 flights, each consisting of a take-off, a transition from hover to forward flight, a climb to at least 500 feet and a landing, at a time when the depression of the centre of the sun was not less than 12° below the horizon;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: he shall not unless his licence includes an instrument rating (helicopters) fly as pilot in command or co-pilot of such a helicopter flying in controlled airspace notified for the purposes of this Schedule in circumstances which require compliance with the Instrument Flight Rules. (L.N. 77 of 2008)

subsection.content: He shall be entitled to fly as co-pilot of any helicopter or gyroplane specified in the aircraft rating included in the licence when the helicopter or gyroplane is engaged on a flight for any purpose whatsoever. (L.N. 77 of 2008)

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.content: He shall not at any time after he attains the age of 60 years fly as pilot in command or co-pilot of any helicopter or gyroplane on any flight for the purposes of public transport unless the helicopter or gyroplane is fitted with dual controls and carries a second pilot who has not attained the age of 60 years and who holds an appropriate licence under this Order entitling him to act as pilot in command or co-pilot of that helicopter or gyroplane. (L.N. 77 of 2008)
He shall not at any time after he attains the age of 65 years act as pilot in command or co-pilot of any helicopter or gyroplane on a flight for the purpose of public transport.

text.b: Airline Transport Pilot’s Licence (Helicopters and Gyroplanes)

schedule.text:
Minimum Age—21 years
Maximum Period of Validity—10 years

text.content: Privileges: The holder of the licence shall be entitled to exercise the privileges of a Commercial Pilot’s Licence (Helicopters and Gyroplanes) except that proviso (b) to paragraph (2) of those privileges shall not apply. (L.N. 77 of 2008)

content.text:
Minimum Age—17 years
No Maximum Period of Validity

Privileges: The holder of the licence shall be entitled to fly as pilot in command of any type of balloon or airship specified in Part 1 of the aircraft rating included in the licence and co-pilot of any type of balloon or airship specified in such aircraft rating:

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he shall not fly such balloon or airship for the purpose of public transport or aerial work, other than aerial work which consists of the giving of instruction in flying or the conducting of flying tests in either case in a balloon or airship owned, or operated under arrangements entered into, by a flying club of which the person giving the instruction or conducting the test and the person receiving the instruction or undergoing the test are both members;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he shall not receive any remuneration for his services as pilot on a flight other than remuneration for the giving of such instruction or the conducting of such flying tests as are specified in paragraph (a) of this proviso;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: he shall not fly such a balloon unless he has within the immediately preceding 13 months carried out as pilot in command in a free balloon 5 flights each of not less than 5 minutes duration.

content.content:
Minimum Age—18 years
Maximum Period of Validity—10 years*(L.N. 77 of 2008)

subsection.content: The holder of the licence shall be entitled to exercise the privileges of a Private Pilot’s Licence (Balloons and Airships).

subsection.leadIn: He shall be entitled to fly, when the balloon is flying for any purpose whatsoever, as pilot in command or co-pilot of any type of balloon specified in the aircraft rating included in the licence:

content.proviso: Provided that he shall not act as pilot in command on a flight for the purpose of the public transport of passengers unless he has within the immediately preceding 90 days carried out as pilot in command in a free balloon 3 flights each of not less than 5 minutes duration.

tr.td: In respect of the privileges of a Private Pilot’s Licence the maximum period of validity shall be as given for that licence.

content.content:
Minimum Age—18 years(L.N. 77 of 2008)
Maximum Period of Validity—10 years

subsection.content: The holder of the licence shall be entitled to exercise the privileges of a Private Pilot’s Licence (Balloons and Airships).

He shall be entitled to fly, when the airship is flying for any purpose whatsoever, as pilot in command of any type of airship specified in Part 1 of the aircraft rating included in the licence and as co-pilot of any type of airship specified in such aircraft rating.

content.text:
Minimum Age—17 years
No Maximum Period of Validity
Privileges:The holder of the licence shall be entitled to fly as pilot in command or co-pilot of a glider of any of the types specified in the aircraft rating included in the licence:

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: he shall not fly such a glider for the purpose of public transport or aerial work other than aerial work which consists of:

subparagraph.name: i
ii

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he shall not receive any remuneration for his services as a pilot on a flight other than remuneration for the giving of such instruction or the conducting of such flying tests as are specified in paragraph (a) of this proviso.

section.name: s0
section.text:
Minimum Age—18 years
Maximum Period of Validity—10 years
Privileges: The holder of the licence shall be entitled to fly for any purpose as pilot in command or co-pilot of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any glider of which the maximum total weight authorized does not exceed 680 kg;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any glider of which the maximum total weight authorized exceeds 680 kg and which is of a type specified in the rating included in the licence.

content.text:
Minimum Age—21 years
Maximum Period of Validity—10 years
Privileges: The holder of the licence shall be entitled to act as flight engineer in any type of aircraft specified in the aircraft rating included in the licence.

Minimum Age—17 years
Maximum Period of Validity—10 years

Privileges: The holder of the licence shall be entitled to operate radiotelephony apparatus in any aircraft if the stability of the frequency radiated by the transmitter is maintained automatically but shall not be entitled to operate the transmitter, or to adjust its frequency, except by the use of external switching devices.(L.N. 77 of 2008)

section.name: s1
section.leadIn: The following ratings may be included in a pilot’s licence granted under Part IV of this Order, and subject to the provisions of this Order and of the licence, the inclusion of a rating in a licence shall have the consequences respectively specified as follows—

proviso.text: Aircraft Ratings: The licence shall entitle the holder to act as pilot of aircraft of the types specified in the aircraft rating and different types of aircraft may be specified in respect of different privileges of a licence.

text.content: Instrument Rating (Aeroplanes) shall entitle the holder of the licence to act as pilot in command or co-pilot of an aeroplane flying in controlled airspace notified for the purpose of this Schedule either in conditions such that he cannot comply with the specified minimum weather provisions or in circumstances which require compliance with the Instrument Flight Rules. (L.N. 77 of 2008)

Instrument Rating (Helicopters) shall entitle the holder of the licence to act as pilot in command or co-pilot of a helicopter flying in controlled airspace notified for the purpose of this Schedule either in conditions such that he cannot comply with the specified minimum weather provisions or in circumstances which require compliance with the Instrument Flight Rules. (L.N. 77 of 2008)

proviso.text: Night Rating (Aeroplanes) shall entitle the holder of a private pilot’s licence (aeroplanes) to act as pilot in command of an aeroplane at night.
Night Rating (Helicopters and Gyroplanes) shall entitle the holder of a private pilot’s licence (helicopters and gyroplanes) to act as pilot in command of a helicopter or gyroplane at night.
Towing Rating (Flying Machines) shall entitle the holder of the licence to act as pilot of a flying machine while towing a glider in flight for the purposes of public transport or aerial work.
Flying Instructor’s Rating shall entitle the holder of the licence to give instruction in flying aircraft of such types as may be specified in the rating for that purpose.
proviso.leadIn: Assistant Flying Instructor’s Rating shall entitle the holder of the licence to give instruction in flying aircraft of such types as may be specified in the rating for that purpose:

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: such instruction shall only be given under the supervision of a person present during the take-off and landing at the aerodrome at which the instruction is to begin and end and holding a pilot’s licence endorsed with a flying instructor’s rating; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: an assistant flying instructor’s rating shall not entitle the holder of the licence to give directions to the person undergoing instruction in respect of the performance by that person of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: his first solo flight;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: his first solo flight by night;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: his first solo cross-country flight otherwise than by night; or

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: his first solo cross-country flight by night.

section.name: s2
section.content: An aircraft rating included in a flight engineer’s licence shall entitle the holder of the licence to act as flight engineer only of aircraft of a type specified in the aircraft rating.

section.name: s3
section.leadIn: For the purposes of this Schedule—
section.def: cross-country flight means any flight during the course of which the aircraft is more than 3 nautical miles from the aerodrome of departure; (E.R. 5 of 2022)
solo flight means a flight on which the pilot of the aircraft is not accompanied by a person holding a pilot’s licence granted or rendered valid under this Order.

text.b: Part C—Certificate of Test or Experience
